sectionTitle: Stock Repurchases: An Alternative to Cash Dividends

columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the reason why a stock a stock repurchase make more sense than an extra cash dividend and the effect of  of a stock repurchase on a firm’s EPS and PE.

## Requirement 17.6a

**Stock Repurchase**, or also known as buyback, is the re-acquisition by a company on its own shares.  A stock repurchase makes more sense than an extra cash dividend because shareholders can choose the timing of their share sales and consequent tax payment. Stock repurchase offer a large tax benefit than extra cash dividends, and shareholders can defer capital gains if the stock price rises.

## Requirement 17.6b

Stock repurchases reduce the number of outstanding firm shares and total assets, resulting in higher earnings per share (EPS). In addition, the price-to-earnings (P/E) ration will be exactly the same whether stock repurchase or cash dividend.
This exercise will contrast the effect of stock dividend declaration and the stock repurchase.

### KEY TERMS

* **Share repurchase (Share buybacks)** - this is where the corporation's shares are previously issued and then reacquired by the issuing entity. These shares are not necessarily canceled, it is just treated as a contra-equity account since it is deducted from the total amount of shareholders’ equity.

* **Earnings per share** - are the income attributable to every outstanding ordinary share during the period. Earnings per share only relate to the ordinary shares issued; preference shares are not included in earnings per share because these shares are entitled to receive a fixed rate of return every year.

* **Price-earnings ratio** -this measures the worth of a particular entity. The price-earnings ratio indicates how much the investors are willing to pay for a dollar's worth of earnings.

### Requirement A

Even though the declaration of stock dividends and shares repurchased are almost the same, the former has an **essential tax advantage** over the other. Whenever dividends are issued, the shareholders were taxed 
for the amount of dividend received. On the other hand, the stockholders are only taxed under the share repurchased when they choose to sell their holdings and the gain arising from that sale is within the threshold for capital gains tax.

### Requirement B

To better understand the effect of stock repurchase on a firm's earnings per share, let us first know how to compute the earnings per share of the entity.

 $$ \begin{aligned}
\text{EPS} &= \dfrac{\text{Net income}-\text{Preference share dividends}}{\text{Common shares outstanding}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

*EPS stands for earnings per share.*

Whenever shares are reacquired by the entity, the shares repurchased will no longer be outstanding. Therefore, the total number of shares repurchased decreases the common shares outstanding that are used as the denominator of the earnings per share formula without a corresponding effect on the net income. A smaller number of common shares outstanding results in higher earnings per share and vice versa.

The following is the formula to calculate the price earnings ratio:
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Price-earnings ratio} &= \dfrac{\text{Price per share}}{\text{Earnings per share}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Since a share repurchased increases the earnings per share of the entity as discussed on the preceding cell, the corresponding price-earnings ratio will decrease.

One of the reasons why corporations buy back their previously issued shares is to make their share of stocks financially attractive. The reacquisition of shares decrease the number of outstanding common shares that is used as a denominator in the earnings per share computation. A higher number of shares repurchase will lead to a higher earnings per share and vice versa.
